Jim
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Gordon Robson 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, March 20, 2006 8:04 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3 setsumei


  Thanks Jim, very fine tsuba with a wonderful signature. The motif is of 
  flowering plum branches, correct?

  Gordon

  On 2006/03/20, at 8:28, Jim Gilbert wrote:

  > I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below. 
  >  I forgot to mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are 
  > 90.1 mm H x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 - 5.5 mm thick at the mimi.
  >
  > The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the type now called 
  > futoji-mei $BB@;zLC(B (bold, thick).  Within both the hanare and futoji-mei 
  > types there is considerable variation in the detail of the signatures. 
  >  This example is not one of the more boldly executed futoji-mei.  As 
  > Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this guard is published 
  > in Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 Nobuie Tsuba shu 
  > (#52).  There the signature is described as sumari-mei $B5M$jLC(B ("close 
  > packed"), which is one of the older terms now included within the 
  > futoji-mei type.  This guard is described as futoji-mei in several 
  > later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.
  >
  > The hitsuana had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made.  This 
  > guard was the property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it 
  > was sold in 1931, so the ana were likely filled by the new owner.  It 
  > is unlikely that they are original to the plate given that they are 
  > made such that the guard would be mounted with the unsigned side as 
  > the front.  The shapes of the hitsuana are unusual.   It was clearly 
  > mounted with an o-kozuka, which are typically 18-20 mm wide (vs. the 
  > standard size of 14-15 mm).  As Gordon mentioned, the small size of 
  > the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of the narrow style 
  > ko-Mino kogai.  The opening is too small to accommodate a standard 
  > 14-15 mm wide kogai.
  >
  > The early Edo period "betsujin" (different person) Nobuie work will 
  > lack the quality in the metal, tekkotsu, finish and carving.  The 
  > plates are usually rather characterless and the working lacks 
  > subtlety.  The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emulate 
  > the finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly 
  > good job.  In general, the working of the rim is a bit forced and 
  > overdone in these examples compared to the originals.  They obviously 
  > will look young, but there is also a somewhat artificial quality to 
  > them.  The same feeling comes from later copies of early Shino and 
  > Oribe ceramics.
  >
  > The metal, tekkotsu and yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin.  
  > Remember that Kaneie worked in Kyoto, and everything about his guards 
  > is in line with Kyoto methods and aesthetics.
  >
  > That's all I can think of at the moment.
  >
  > Jim
  >
  >
  >
